reviewText:
Fans of the original release should be wary of purchasing this steam re-release. Instead of using Direct3D it uses something called nGlide, this means that you no longer have the bump-mapping of the original nor do you have the option of true colour textures (this being a game made back when 16bit colour was actally an option).
On top of this the crosshairs are noticeably off center making long-range engagements more difficult, especially now since the lock-on missiles no longer work.

Until these issues are fixed I shall not recommend this game.
voteText: 77 of 82 people (94%) found this review helpful 4 people found this review funny

reviewText:
ok, just have to say this first. Don't take my lack of hours in steam as anything.
I played this game and finished it years ago when it was new and was very happy when i found it on steam recently.

Slave Zero is a classic mech game that i feel no one else has ever pulled off quite like this.
The levels are different levels of a massive populated futuristic city. when you finish the stage you either jump into a massive elevator to the next area of the city or go through blast doors.
you can use a lot of the environment as weapons.
such as the people walking around, the cars on the highways, you can destroy buildings to get iron pipes to club enemy mechs and police helicopters. you also can replenish health and ammo destroying buildings.
the levels while you would expect for a game its age are a little linear you can still explore to an extent. the game is challenging in a good way as you find better weapons to fight your foes on the enemies you have already crushed.
the boss battles are challenging and oldschool where you find the weak spot and keep attacking it when the opportunity arises. the game is also littered with lesser bosses that you just have to be quick and deal as much damage as possible.
i feel i should also mention the soundtrack. it is fantastic and compliments the game extreamly well.

ah yes, and strafe is your friend!

so happy this is now on steam as i get to relive a piece of my childhood.
if you have never played it i highly recommend it. it of course is showing its age now but that does not distract from the excellent core gameplay.

OS while i can't speak for Windows 8 i can say with pure confidence this game runs exceptionally on windows 7 and as yet i have not encountered any bugs. i do think the controlls need to be remapped for the best gaming experience. however that is down to personal preference. textures are a bit blurry but that is to be expected from a game this old. as far as i know there are no texture packs available. but that does not change the fact the game itself is still incredible. please, if you run win 8 and buy this don't hesitate to drop me a comment. i would love to know how it runs.

Aspect Ratio its pretty much locked to 4:3 but there are a myriad of resolutions to choose from that range from 640x480 to 7680x4320

i highly recommend picking it up.

11/10 - glad to be throwing humans at giant mechs once more.

reviewText: Thanks to a PC Gamer demo disc I played this game when I was a kid.  The game was fun then, and its fun now!  The game definitely feels easier than I remember, but a lot of old games feel that way.  Some of the graphics options are not compatible with current gen hardware but that is to be expected, they are red and cannot be selected in game.  The game still runs great on my three year old windows 7 hardware.  I would have liked to see a few updates with it, like better textures, but it's not that important.  Anyways, this is a fun linear third person shooter that reminds me of the good old days, check it out!

reviewText:
I remember when I first got this game some 14 years ago, I went into it blind and loved every moment of it. I still do. When I saw it on steam, I had to get it.

It's amusing looking at reviews from back in the day that were generally unfair to the game.

The game's essentially a run-and-gun game in 3D with cutscenes thrown in, and it lives up that description. Essentially you point your gun at things that shoot at you and hold down the mouse button while running towards the end of the game. It's more about taking part in the journey of getting through the game and enjoying the scenery than it is putting your skills to the test, and the game somehow still looks okay to this day. I think reviewers 15 years ago were expecting Slave Zero to be a different game than what it is -- but what it is is perfectly fine from my point of view.

Well, if you like run and gun games, and you want to see how they were done around the year 2000, Slave Zero is a nice experience. It's also short enough to get through in one afternon.

reviewText:
A++++

FINALLY SLAVE ZERO IS ON STEAM!

This brings back memories, and after not playing it for a decade or so I am re-adjusted to the controls and playstyle in a matter of seconds.

It's a very enjoyable action shooter.  Everyone must own it!  But the graphics are a bit dated by today's standards.  Still better than some stuff pumped out today.

If I play for a few hours back to back I'll come back to this review and add to it, but I just wanted to leave my +1 for now!  And I agree with what the others have said, the Steam port for this is very good.  It's just the perfect release of this game, the only thing better that they could have done would be release a sequel!

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8WKiUOpAbEM

http://pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Slave_Zero

Slave Zero is repetitive, but fun third person shooter with a lot of things to blow up. It have some flaws, but it doesn't overstay it's welcome.

It's 500 years in to the future. The game takes place in the capital of asian conglomerates – Megacity S1-9. The sovereign khan has taken it over with the help of giant biomechanical robots (or Slaves as they are called in the game). But not all hope is lost. An underground resistance known as The Guardians, stole one of those Slaves and now it's up to you the merge body and mind with him and save everyone, The story is paper thin. I wish for more detailed story, not just good vs evil, but this is what you get. This is a game focused entirely on action, not story and the action is good.

The released date is 1999, so of course the graphics are dated, but still it's nice too look at.

The gameplay is pretty straight forward. You are in control of giant mech that can stomp, throw cars or pieces of buildings or shoot his three weapons or weapon types to be precise – rockets, energy and balistic.  Through the whole game you will find upgrades for them. Some are hidden, but it's not necessery to search for them. Soon or later you will get them. All you need to do is run, gun, strafe and not get shot. All three weapon types are useful and their ammo runs fast, so you will be changing between them constantly. But don't worry, there is plenty health and ammo packs lying around. When enemy gets closer you can punch him to death. Also you can do this to buildings.

Level design is good. Most of the times you will be high in the sky, between bulding, killing innocent civilians from time to time, but there are also sewer, inside bases and so on. This is corridor shooter, so no exploration is required. Later levels can give you some headache. Seem like the city was build so high and you can fall to your doom. This is especially annoying, when some of the enemies can knock back you with a single shot and there is no way of defending againts that. I recommend saving often on those levels.

There is one impressive thing for a such an old game – level destruction. Bridges, buildings and so on. A lot of things in the envoirment can be demolish and with the combination of constantly attacking enemies, things can get hectic, but in a fun way.

Enemies are diverse. In the beginning helicopters, tanks and small mechs will attack you. Later you will face tougher with shields, armed with lazer that do tons of damage, flying robots, small annoying and fast, that attach to you and leach your life and so on.

I always look for a good boss battle. Here some are good, some are bad and some even annoying. Some are just not that fun, than others. A static giant mother ship pumping out mechs is not that interesting. But there some quite enjoyble to fight, like one that have really powerful weapons and you have constantly to go up, because there is rasing acid below you. It was quite tense battle. The final boss was disappointment to me. Just shoot, hide, get more ammo, rinse and repeat. The fight was not very creative. You have to hide from him because he do insane amount of damage.

Beside the bosses I have few other issies with the game. There is only three weapons. You can argue that, because with the upgrades the numbers is getting higher, but they are just that upgrades, not new weapons, although they fire differently. Let me have them all, it is action game, where you can blow stuff, you need more weapon variety. My next problem is the repetition. As much as I like the game, I can say that after the first hour you will see everything that the game offers, but still I find the gameplay enjoyable. It took me 5 h to beat it and as I said in the beginning it doesn't overstay it's welcome. Another small problem is that I took my a while to make the game run in 1080 p, but this maybe entirely my fault.

The sound design is great, especially the music. Fantastic fast techno tracks, fitting extremely well with the sci-fi setting and the action on screen. Sound fx are also great. Stomping and walking felt like i'm really in control of giant mech. And you can also distinct all weapons.

At the end of the day the question I have to answer is – does the game hold up? Yeah, to some degree. Graphics don't, but the gameplay is solid and controls are tight.  In the end I can say, I had fun playin the game. Non stop action, where you can blow a lot of things and you play as a giant mech. Whats not to like? I was impressed mostly with the level destruction. The game came out 16 years ago and I think it is an accomplishment. It have some problems, but nothing to make me quit. Slave Zero probably won't be stuck for a long in my mind. It doesn't have the nostalgia for me like Max Payne for example, but I still recommend it.

reviewText:
This is a game filled with nostalgia and quite epic. We don't see much Mecha games nowadays.
You feel really powerful as a giant robot walking into a futuristic maze-like city, playing your role as an anti-hero who fights the powerful tyranny of SovKhan while grabbing cars and even people, to throw them at walls or other robots.
There's no pause, it's all action.

Recommending this game in these days is hard, not many people will have the will to disregard such old graphics and play it for the pure fun. But people like me, who had or still have the game CD (yes, in that magazine) will have no doubt to jump right in and own a copy. Having your old games in the cloud and updated to run on modern OS is really convenient, definitely worth the price.
And the game as a concept, I find this have a lot of potential for a remake.
